CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-f - Extradition);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Review of lawfulness of detention;Take proceedings)
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Erik Møse;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lived in GPE and was involved in the activities of NORP - ut - GPE ( “ ORG ” ) , a pan - NORP organisation banned in GPE . In DATE he moved to GPE , leaving behind his wife and QUANTITY children , born in DATE and DATE , in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in GPE on drug - related charges ( LAW ( “ the ORG ” ) ) . His NORP passport was confiscated upon arrest . On DATE the ORG of GPE sentenced him to imprisonment . After his release on DATE , the applicant arrived in GPE , where he started a relationship with a NORP national . It appears that she was residing in GPE unlawfully at the material time . They have CARDINAL minor children born in DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG of GPE charged the applicant , in absentia , with attempting to overthrow the existing regime under LAW ( a and b ) of LAW ( “ the ORG ” ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE regional prosecutor ordered the applicant ’s placement in custody and put his name on a search list .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was additionally charged with setting up a criminal group ( Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the ORG ) , producing and disseminating documents containing a threat to national security and public order ( LAW ( a and c ) of the ORG ) , and setting up , managing and participating in extremist , separatist , fundamentalist and other banned organisations ( Article CARDINAL of the ORG ) .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date his name was put on the international wanted list .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by the police in GPE as a person wanted by the NORP authorities . On DATE ORG submitted a formal request asking its NORP counterpart to extradite the applicant on criminal charges under ORG CARDINAL ( a and b ) , CARDINAL - CARDINAL , CARDINAL ( a and c ) and CARDINAL of the ORG . Relying on LAW ( “ the FAC ” ) , the NORP authorities provided assurances that the applicant would not be extradited to a third country without the consent of GPE , that he would not be prosecuted , tried or punished for an offence which was not the subject of the extradition request and that he would be able to freely leave GPE , once the court proceedings had terminated and the sentence served . On DATE ORG received the extradition request .

CARDINAL . Thereafter , ORG carried out a preliminary check of the extradition request ( “ an extradition check ” ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It can be seen from the information collected DATE by ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) and ORG , that the applicant was an NORP national who had not applied for NORP citizenship or temporary asylum or registered his residence in GPE . The said authorities saw no obstacle to his extradition to GPE . Moreover , on DATE the ORG submitted that the applicant was “ certainly a functionary ” of ORG and recommended that he be extradited .

CARDINAL . On DATE the deputy Prosecutor General granted the extradition request and issued an extradition order in respect of the applicant . He referred to the charges brought against the applicant , according to which he had been a founding manager and financial supporter of ORG , had created a number of sub - groups of the said organisation in GPE and actively participated in the dissemination of its subversive materials , characterised as extremist , separatist and fundamentalist . The prosecutor decided to extradite the applicant on charges of setting up a criminal group and participating therein ( Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG ) and attempting to overthrow the existing regime and constitutional order ( LAW . He noted that the statute of limitations for those offences had not expired either in GPE or in GPE . The prosecutor further pointed out that , in line with LAW and LAW ( “ the CCrP ” ) , differences in the legal classification of the offences and their elements under NORP and NORP criminal law were not sufficient grounds for refusing extradition . Lastly , the prosecutor referred to the information provided by the ORG that the applicant was an NORP national who had not applied for NORP citizenship . The prosecutor concluded that there were no obstacles to his extradition to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the extradition order was served on the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sought judicial review of the extradition order , referring , inter alia , to a fear of torture and inhuman and degrading treatment , in particular , on account of his connections with ORG . The applicant ’s appeal was supported with his lawyer ’s claims of CARDINAL DATE and DATE that torture remained a widespread practice in GPE , according to reports of numerous international organisations and recent media publications .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Saratov ORG upheld the extradition order , relying on the assurances issued by ORG that the applicant would be treated in strict compliance with internal procedural norms . It also referred to the dismissal of the applicant ’s request for refugee status by the ORG on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the applicant and his lawyer appealed . On DATE ORG of GPE set aside the judgment of DATE and ordered a new judicial review by the first - instance court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG re - examined the case and annulled the extradition order of CARDINAL DATE , mainly because of inconsistencies and mistakes made in the comparative assessment of the relevant criminal offences under NORP and LANGUAGE law . In addition , the court made the following findings :

“ ... The allegation of a risk of ill - treatment should be dismissed because the case file contains written assurances made by the deputy Prosecutor General of GPE who affirmed that prosecution of the applicant would be in strict conformity with LAW ... The court has no reason to distrust these guarantees ...

Article CARDINAL of the NORP CCrP prohibits the extradition of a person who has been granted asylum in GPE on account of persecution in the requesting State because of his race , religion , citizenship , ethnic or social origin or political beliefs .

Prior to the date of the extradition order , [ the applicant ] had applied for refugee status and had subsequently sought judicial review of the refusal of such status in GPE . Such review proceedings have not been completed . Taking into account paragraph CARDINAL and CARDINAL of section CARDINAL of LAW , a person can not be extradited before a court decision has been taken on judicial review of a refusal of refugee status . Thus , the extradition order was premature , in breach of LAW ... ”
The applicant was released in the courtroom .
CARDINAL . NORP The regional prosecutor ’s office appealed . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . In view of the above findings , the extradition case against the applicant was not pursued and his removal from GPE to GPE on that account became impossible .
CARDINAL . From DATE to CARDINAL DATE the applicant was detained with a view to extradition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by the police in GPE as a person wanted by the NORP authorities . He was placed in remand centre no . CARDINAL . According to the Government , the applicant made no allegation of a risk of ill - treatment in the event of his extradition to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , referring to LAW CCrP the deputy district prosecutor lodged an application asking ORG of Saratov to authorise the applicant ’s detention . Relying on LAW ORG , the district court granted this request and ordered the applicant ’s detention until DATE with a view to his extradition to GPE . The court observed that the applicant had been charged with offences punishable under LAW , CARDINAL - CARDINAL , CARDINAL - CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL of the ORG ; that the statute of limitations for the said offences had not expired either in GPE or in GPE ; that the applicant , an NORP national , had not registered his residence in GPE and had absconded there ; and that , given the state of the applicant ’s health , he was fit for detention . The applicant and his lawyer did not appeal against the detention order of CARDINAL DATE . It became final on DATE .

CARDINAL . After receipt of the NORP extradition request and before the expiry of the time - limit set in the detention order of CARDINAL DATE , the deputy district prosecutor lodged an application asking the district court to extend the applicant ’s detention . On DATE the district court extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The court dismissed the applicant ’s argument that his detention would put his underage children in a difficult financial situation and that he had lodged an application for refugee status . The court concluded as follows :

“ Under LAW CCrP a preventive measure may be varied if it is no longer necessary or if the grounds justifying it ( see ORG and CARDINAL of the Code ) have changed . The available material does not disclose that any such grounds have changed in the present case ... ”
CARDINAL . The applicant and his lawyer appealed on CARDINAL and DATE . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeals .
CARDINAL . On DATE the district court examined a new extension request from the prosecutor and extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE . The court held as follows :

“ [ The applicant ] sought judicial review of the extradition decision against him ... Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG provide that a preventive measure may be varied if it is no longer necessary or if the grounds justifying it ( see Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code ) have changed .

Extension of detention beyond DATE may be allowed only in respect of persons charged with serious and particularly serious criminal offences and only on account of the exceptional complexity of the case ... The available material discloses that the extradition order could not be enforced , where the previous detention order was in force , because the applicant had applied for judicial review of the extradition order . These are objective circumstances disclosing the particular complexity of the case . Thus , the extension term mentioned in the request is reasonable ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant and his lawyer appealed , seeking house arrest instead of detention in a remand centre . On DATE ORG upheld the detention order of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant ’s detention until DATE , pending the re - examination of the extradition case by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined an extension request by the district prosecutor and issued a new detention order extending the applicant ’s detention to CARDINAL DATE pending judicial review of the extradition order . The court noted that LAW ORG allowed the extension of detention DATE in relation to serious and particularly serious charges and on account of the particular complexity of the case . The court was satisfied that the above conditions had been complied with in respect of the applicant . On DATE ORG upheld the detention order of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released from detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE or DATE the applicant lodged a request for refugee status with ORG of GPE ( “ the regional FMS ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE he submitted an additional request , whereby he expressed a fear of being subjected to persecution and torture owing to his previous membership of ORG - ut - GPE . He referred to a number of international reports in support of his allegations .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in an interview with a regional ORG officer conducted in the presence of his lawyer , the applicant submitted that he had left GPE for work - related reasons .

CARDINAL . On DATE the regional ORG rejected the applicant ’s request for refugee status . The authority noted that the applicant had left GPE in DATE for economic reasons whereas criminal proceedings against him had not been brought until DATE in his country of origin . He had been prosecuted for having set up a criminal group , which was not a political crime under the ORG . Furthermore , the applicant had not lodged his application for refugee status until DATE . The ORG established that he faced no risk of persecution on account of his origin , religion , nationality or belonging to a particular social group . It concluded that the applicant did not wish to return to GPE so as to avoid prosecution for the crime with which he had been charged .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was informed of the above - mentioned decision and lodged a hierarchical appeal on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the FMS Central Office dismissed his appeal . The ORG referred to the decision of ORG of DATE to declare ORG a terrorist organisation and ban its activity in GPE . The ORG emphasised the applicant ’s involvement in ORG in DATE as a manager and financial supporter . It pointed out that in DATE at the latest the applicant had learnt from his brother that the GPE authorities had begun prosecuting ORG members . However , it was not until DATE that the applicant had submitted his request for refugee status . Hence , the ORG concluded that the applicant ’s fear of persecution was unsubstantiated .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the refusal to grant him refugee status to ORG of GPE . He reiterated his fear of being subjected to torture in the event of extradition to GPE and stated that the risk of ill - treatment had not been assessed by the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the decision of DATE on judicial review . Noting that the applicant had confirmed his involvement in ORG ’s activities DATE , the court also observed that after his arrest in DATE the applicant had made no official statement to NORP or NORP authorities distancing himself from ORG teachings or his previous participation in its activities . The court held as follows :

“ After his arrival in GPE the applicant did not apply for refugee status . He first alleged a risk of persecution in GPE and raised his wish to remain in GPE as a refugee after having been arrested following the request from the NORP authorities .

Neither following his arrival in GPE in DATE nor during criminal proceedings in DATE did he distance himself from ORG teachings or state his refusal to participate in its activities . He did not apply for refugee status when he learnt in DATE from his younger brother that his fellow ORG supporters were being looked for and tortured by the NORP authorities ...
Had the applicant ’s fears of persecution in GPE been truly justified , he would have immediately sought asylum in the country of his destination .

ORG indicates that persecution must be distinguished from punishment for a common law offence . Persons fleeing from prosecution or punishment for such an offence are not normally refugees . It should be borne in mind that a refugee is a victim – or potential victim – of injustice , not a fugitive from justice ( paragraph CARDINAL ) ...
The applicant has not adduced convincing arguments concerning religious or political persecution ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for temporary asylum . It was refused on DATE .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE , refusing the applicant refugee status . Endorsing the reasoning of the first - instance court , the appeal court added the following :

“ ORG affirms its attachment to their obligations in relation to protecting human rights . The NORP legislation provides that every citizen has freedom of religion . Article CARDINAL of LAW protects equality of citizens before the law irrespective of gender , race , national language , religion , faith or social origin ...

The court dismisses as unconvincing the arguments relating to the individualised status of the applicant on account of criminal prosecution in GPE . Neither during his residence in GPE nor immediately after his arrival in GPE did the applicant seek asylum . He first expressed his fears of persecution in GPE after his arrest because his name had been added to the international wanted list ...

Taking into account ORG and Criteria for Determining Refugee Status ( paragraph CARDINAL ) , in order to be considered a refugee , a person must show well - founded fear of persecution . Discrimination may turn into persecution when it becomes impossible to carry out work in specific areas , to receive education or if other freedoms protected in democratic societies are limited ... The applicant has not substantiated any facts concerning unlawful persecution ... ”

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE , ORG of the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees ( UNHCR ) Representation informed the applicant ’s lawyer that the ORG had determined that the applicant met the criteria set out in its Statute in connection with LAW A of the DATE Convention relating to LAW . It had been ascertained that the applicant was outside his country of nationality owing to well - founded fear of being persecuted by the authorities of his country for reasons of his religion and imputed political opinion and , owing to such fear , was unable to return to GPE , where he might be exposed to torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment . Therefore , the ORG considered that the applicant was eligible for international protection under its mandate .

CARDINAL . Everyone has a right to liberty and security ( LAW ) . Detention is permissible only on the basis of a court order . The length of time for which a person may be detained prior to obtaining such an order must not exceed TIME ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The term “ court ” is defined by LAW ( “ the CCrP ” ) of DATE as “ any court of general jurisdiction which examines a criminal case on the merits and delivers decisions provided for by LAW ” ( LAW ) . The term “ judge ” is defined by the ORG as “ an official empowered to administer justice ” ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . A district court has the power to examine all criminal cases except for those falling within the respective jurisdictions of a justice of the peace , a regional court or ORG ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . LAW of the CCrP governs the application of preventive measures . Detention is a preventive measure applied on the basis of a court decision to a person suspected of or charged with a criminal offence punishable by DATE imprisonment where it is impossible to apply a more lenient preventive measure ( LAW ) . A court request for detention is submitted by an investigator ( следователь ) with the support of the head of the investigative authority or by a police officer in charge of the inquiry ( дознаватель ) with the support of a prosecutor ( LAW ) . A request for detention should be examined by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level in the presence of the person concerned ( LAW ) . Second - instance courts should examine appeals lodged against judge ’s decisions on detention within DATE ( LAW ) . The period of detention pending investigation of a criminal case must not exceed DATE ( LAW ) but may be extended DATE by a judge of a district court or a military court of a corresponding level . Further extensions DATE may be granted with regard to persons accused of serious or particularly serious criminal offences ( LAW ) . Extensions DATE may be granted as an exception with regard to persons accused of particular serious criminal offences ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . A measure of restraint can be applied with a view to ensuring a person ’s extradition in compliance with the procedure established under LAW ) .
CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL of the CCrP ( Articles CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) governs the procedure to be followed in the event of extradition .

CARDINAL . A court is to review the lawfulness and validity of a decision to extradite within DATE of receipt of a request for review . The decision should be taken in open court by a panel of CARDINAL judges in the presence of a prosecutor , the person whose extradition is sought and the latter ’s legal counsel ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL lists the conditions under which extradition can not be authorised . Thus , the extradition of the following should be denied : a NORP citizen ( LAW ) or a person who was granted asylum in GPE ( LAW ) ; a person in respect of whom a conviction became effective or criminal proceedings were terminated in GPE in connection with the same act for which he or she has been prosecuted in the requesting ORG ( LAW ) ; a person in respect of whom criminal proceedings can not be launched and a conviction can not become effective in view of the expiry of the statute of limitations or under another valid ground under LANGUAGE law ( LAW ) ; or a person in respect of whom a NORP court established obstacles to extradition , in accordance with the legislation and international treaties of GPE ( LAW ) . Finally , extradition should be denied if the act that gave grounds for the extradition request does not constitute a criminal offence under the ORG ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In the event that a foreign national , whose extradition is being sought , is being prosecuted or is serving a penalty for another criminal offence in GPE , his extradition may be postponed until the prosecution is terminated , the penalty is lifted on any valid ground or the sentence is served ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition not accompanied by an arrest warrant issued by a foreign court , ORG or his deputy is to “ take measures ” in order to decide on the preventive measure in respect of the person whose extradition is being sought . The preventive measure is to be applied in accordance with the established procedure ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Upon receipt of a request for extradition accompanied by an arrest warrant issued by a foreign judicial body , a prosecutor may place the person whose extradition is being sought under house arrest or in custodial detention without prior approval of his or her decision by a court of GPE ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Verifying the compatibility of section GPE ) of the Law on the Legal Status of Foreign Nationals in the GPE of DATE , ORG ruled that a foreign national liable to be expelled from NORP territory could not be detained for CARDINAL without a court order .

CARDINAL . Assessing the compatibility of LAW of the CCrP with LAW , ORG reiterated its settled case - law to the effect that excessive or arbitrary detention , unlimited in time and without appropriate review , was incompatible with LAW in all cases , including extradition proceedings .

CARDINAL . In ORG view , the absence of specific regulation of detention matters in LAW did not create a legal lacuna incompatible with LAW . LAW ORG provided that , in executing a request for legal assistance , the requested party would apply its domestic law , that is the procedure laid down in the GPE That procedure comprised , in particular , LAW and the norms in its LAW ( “ Preventive measures ” ) , which , by virtue of their general character and position in Part I of the LAW ( “ General provisions ” ) , applied to all stages and forms of criminal proceedings , including proceedings for the examination of extradition requests .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court emphasised that the guarantees of the right to liberty and personal integrity set out in LAW were fully applicable to detention with a view to extradition . Accordingly , LAW ORG did not allow the authorities to apply a custodial measure without complying with the procedure established in the ORG or in excess of the time - limits fixed in the LAW .

CARDINAL . The Prosecutor General asked ORG for official clarification of its decision no . CARDINAL-O of DATE ( see above ) , for the purpose , in particular , of elucidating the procedure for extending a person ’s detention with a view to extradition .

CARDINAL . ORG refused the request on the ground that it was not competent to indicate specific provisions of the criminal law governing the procedure and time - limits for holding a person in custody with a view to extradition . That matter was within the competence of the courts of general jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court reiterated its settled case - law to the effect that the scope of the constitutional right to liberty and personal inviolability was the same for foreign nationals and stateless persons as for NORP nationals . A foreign national or stateless person may not be detained in GPE for more than TIME without a judicial decision . That constitutional requirement served as a guarantee against excessively long detention beyond TIME , and also against arbitrary detention as such , in that it required a court to examine whether the arrest was lawful and justified .

CARDINAL . ORG held that LAW CCrP , read in conjunction with LAW , could not be construed as permitting the detention of an individual for DATE on the basis of a request for his or her extradition without a decision by a NORP court . A custodial measure could be applied only in accordance with the procedure established in the ORG and within the time - limits fixed in the LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG dismissed as inadmissible a request for a review of the constitutionality of LAW of the ORG , stating that this provision “ does not establish time - limits for custodial detention and does not establish the reasons and procedure for choosing a preventive measure , it merely confirms a prosecutor ’s power to execute a decision already delivered by a competent judicial body of a foreign state to detain an accused . Therefore the disputed norm can not be considered to violate constitutional rights of [ the claimant ] ... ”

CARDINAL . In Ruling no . CARDINAL , adopted by LAW of ORG of GPE on DATE ( “ the Ruling of CARDINAL DATE ” ) , it was stated that , pursuant to LAW ORG , only a court could order the placement in custody of a person in respect of whom an extradition check was pending and where the authorities of the country requesting extradition had not submitted a court decision remanding him or her in custody . The judicial authorisation of placement in custody in that situation was to be carried out in accordance with LAW of the ORG and following a prosecutor ’s request for that person to be placed in custody ( paragraph CARDINAL of the Ruling ) . In deciding to remand a person in custody a court was to examine if there were factual and legal grounds for the application of that preventive measure . If the extradition request was accompanied by a detention order of a foreign court , a prosecutor was entitled to remand the person in custody without a NORP court ’s authorisation ( LAW ORG ) for a period not exceeding DATE , and the prosecutor ’s decision could be challenged in the courts under LAW
CARDINAL . In extending a person ’s detention with a view to extradition a court was to apply LAW

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG Office issued Direction no . CARDINAL concerning the “ extradition check ” procedure for dealing with requests for extradition . According to the Direction , district and town prosecutors should interview a person who has been detained with a view to extradition , submit the interview record to ORG within TIME and take measures to ensure this person ’s placement in custody for TIME . Having received confirmation from the requesting State of their intention to seek extradition , these officials should take measures for authorising the person ’s detention , in compliance with GPE ’s international treaties and the applicable national legislation . These public officials should also interview the detainee in order to ascertain the purpose of his arrival in GPE , his residence , nationality and intention to seek asylum in GPE ; to verify the authenticity of the documents relating to his identity and nationality ; and to verify the existence and veracity of information relating to the possible refusal or postponement of extradition . The information and documents collected during the extradition check should be submitted , within DATE of the person ’s arrest , to the regional prosecutor .

CARDINAL . GPE is a party to the LAW relating to LAW , adopted on DATE by ORG on the Status of Refugees and Stateless Persons convened under ORG resolution CARDINAL ( V ) of CARDINAL DATE . LAW reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . No Contracting State shall expel or return ( “ refouler ” ) a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion .

CARDINAL . NORP The benefit of the present provision may not , however , be claimed by a refugee whom there are reasonable grounds for regarding as a danger to the security of the country in which he is , or who , having been convicted by a final judgment of a particularly serious crime , constitutes a danger to the community of that country . ”
CARDINAL . In DATE ORG High Commissioner for Refugees issued an ORG on GPE under LAW relating to LAW ; it provides the following clarification [ internal footnotes are omitted ] :

“ CARDINAL . The prohibition of refoulement to a danger of persecution under international refugee law is applicable to any form of forcible removal , including deportation , expulsion , extradition , informal transfer or “ renditions ” , and non - admission at the border in the circumstances described below . This is evident from the wording of Article PERSON ) of the DATE Convention , which refers to expulsion or return ( refoulement ) “ in any manner whatsoever ” . It applies not only in respect of return to the country of origin or , in the case of a stateless person , the country of former habitual residence , but also to any other place where a person has reason to fear threats to his or her life or freedom related to CARDINAL or more of the grounds set out in the DATE Convention , or from where he or she risks being sent to such a risk .

CARDINAL . The principle of non - refoulement as provided for in Article PERSON ) of LAW does not , as such , entail a right of the individual to be granted asylum in a particular ORG . It does mean , however , that where GPE are not prepared to grant asylum to persons who are seeking international protection on their territory , they must adopt a course that does not result in their removal , directly or indirectly , to a place where their lives or freedom would be in danger on account of their race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion . As a general rule , in order to give effect to their obligations under LAW and/or DATE LAW will be required to grant individuals seeking international protection access to the territory and to fair and efficient asylum procedures . ”
